awd_titl_txt: AF:Small:Geometric and Combinatoric Algorithms for Contact and Intersection Representation of Graphs
awd_abstract_narration:
Networks of nodes connected by links are a useful abstraction in many areas -- from sociology and biology to engineering and transportation. Networks are used to model causal structures, hierarchies, and scheduling. Although networks are typically drawn as node-link diagrams, several areas use geometric representations of networks (molecules in chemistry or floor-plans in engineering). This project explores intersection and contact representation of networks, where nodes are geometric objects (e.g., rectangles, segments) and links are realized by intersections (e.g., segments crossing) or contacts between the objects (e.g., rectangular duals). A geometric representation is more than just a way to display the network; it reveals underlying combinatorial structures which can often be described only using geometry. The goal of this project is to leverage these connections and build new bridges between geometry and combinatorics, in order to develop algorithms for intersection and contact representations of networks, with broader impact in information visualization, network analysis, and computational cartography. Educational activities, such as new coursework development, graduate and undergraduate student advising and outreach are integral parts of this project.  Finally, continuing the investigator's tradition of implementing new algorithms and deploying software, dissemination of results will not only be accomplished by publishing in scientific journals, organizing workshops and seminars, but also by making software and data available.

The specific research agenda is to identify connections between geometry and combinatorics in the context of intersection and contact representations of graphs. As a result of studying the classes of graphs that can be represented as contacts between simple polygons (e.g., triangles and quadrilaterals), the combinatorial properties of these graph classes will be used to design algorithms for constructing such representations. Efficient algorithms will be designed and implemented for constructing proportional (value-by-area) contact representations and for creating static and dynamic cartograms. These problems are addressed on two fronts: (a) by finding necessary and sufficient conditions for specific types of intersection and contact representation, developing new representation algorithms, and establishing tight bounds for the problems; and (b) by directly applying the theoretical results to practical problems in information visualization and cartography, as well as implementing and experimentally evaluating the new methods, which are made available as fully functional online systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project was to study graph theoretical problems in a geometric setting. Graphs (also known as networks) are the central object of interest in many of today's most important challenges, both in theory and practice. Fundamental questions, from biology and physics to engineering and social sciences, are best stated in the simple and abstract, yet powerful and flexible language of graphs. Graphs naturally model social networks, biological networks, and transportation networks, but also causal structures, hierarchies, and scheduling. A good geometric representation of a graph not only gives a useful way of understanding its structure, but can lead to algorithmic solutions of purely graph-theoretic questions seemingly unrelated to geometry.  

The main goals of the project were:

1. To study contact and intersection representation of graphs, where vertices are geometric objects (e.g., circles, rectangles, segments) and edges are realized by contacts between the objects (e.g., kissing circles, rectangular duals, cartograms) or intersections (e.g., segment intersection).

2. To design efficient algorithms for geometric graph representation and utilize them in visualization applications, such as graph drawing and network visualization.

3. To design, implement and make available practical algorithms for creating cartograms based on solid theoretical foundations, as well as design and implement algorithms for evolving and dynamic cartograms.

We made progress on many of the goals above, as well in several new research directions. Specifically, more that 20 publications appeared in peer-reviewed conferences and journals, and the work was driven by postdoctoral associates, PhD students, and undergraduate research assistants who were partially supported by this project.

Several of the publications originating from this project are associated with software and tools. We make all such software available online where they are used by colleagues. Some of the tools developed are available online and used by thousands of people; examples include:

  • GMap: A Graph-based Map visualization tool, uses the geographic map metaphor to visualize relational or metric data, implemented and available in the graphviz package.
  • MPSE: Multi-Perspective, Simultaneous Embedding (MPSE) allows one to visualize multiple relationships defined on the same set of objects.
  • MetroSets: Visualizing set systems (also known as hypergraphs) using the metro map metaphor.
